front.p: 1838 January 31: Octavius Hadfield to his father Joseph

body.p: I wrote a few hurried lines to my mother last evening and now write a few more to you today chiefly to say that I think there is not much chance of the ship's sailing until next week. I shall therefore have time to get all that I want, and I hope I shall hear from home, as I fear from my letter of yesterday that you might think I might be off before I could hear from you. I am much pleased with the ship and my cabin. I might have a cabin on the poop, I should have more air and light, but much more noise and other inconveniences. I liked the look of the Captain he appeared a gentlemanlike fellow. There are, I think, ten passengers and I am not aware that there are any emigrants.

I heard from George today. I saw Mr. Warren; he said when I found out what I wanted he would give me the money to pay for them. I shall see him in town again tomorrow and hope he is well. He told me he heard from you on Monday. I have been busy all day and am now going to pass the evening with Mr. Jowett. I want to hear from you while I can. I hope you are better. Tell some of my sisters to write to me.
Letters put into the post addressed to me at New Zealand via Sydney will reach me without difficulty.

I called on Cap. Duff today but he was out. If the ship does not sail until next week I shall be able to see some of our friends in town. I send my kind regards to all. Give my love to all at home, and believe me ever,

Octavius Hadfield./
I have just written to George.
I write in haste.
